item.title: E07: Junwon's Notes on The Innovator's Dilemma
item.description: On profit margin Clayton Christensen focused on studying disruptive technologies that are simpler and cheaper than sustaining technologies. He explained that because these disruptive technologies create lower profit margins, established firms are incapable of finding the willingness to compete against the disruptive firms.

item.title: E03: Upward Mobility and Downward Immobility
item.description: Disruptive technological change Disruptive technological change happens in 6 steps. Step 1: Disruptive technologies were first developed within established firms. Established firms led in research and development of disruptive technologies, but entrants led in commercializing them.

item.title: E04: The Solutions to The Innovator’s Dilemma
item.description: Managing Disruptive Technological Change It is not enough to understand the future needs of the customers and develop new technologies to satisfy them.

item.title: E05: The Organizational Capabilities Framework
item.description: Components of the Organizational Capabilities The capabilities of the organization is not the same as the capabilities of the individuals in the organization.

item.title: E06: Product Life Cycle
item.description: A company faces the need to grow infinitely, but the size of any market is finite. As a result, the company is forced to increase the price of its products by supplying more performance even when the market does not demand it.

item.title: E01: Disruptive Innovation
item.description: Failure of great companies The Innovator’s Dilemma is a book about the failure of companies. Not just of simply any company, but of great companies.

item.title: E02: Value Networks
item.description: Disruptive technology redefines performance metrics Blindly following the maxim that good managers should keep close to their customers can be a fatal mistake.

item.title: Microsoft Vision Model ResNet-50
item.description: Microsoft Research: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/microsoft-vision-model-resnet-50-combines-web-scale-data-and-multi-task-learning-to-achieve-state-of-the-art/ I am excited to announce on behalf of my team at Microsoft that we not only set a new state-of-the-art in general pretrained vision models, we are also publicly releasing this model for the research community and the industry.

item.title: Product CEO 21H1
item.description: Post Mortem In 2020, Product CEO successfully launched Library of Business, Executive Summary, and First Party. A sufficient amount of content was accumulated for distribution.

item.title: E01: How to Write a Great Business Plan
item.description: William Sahlman, a Baker Foundation Professor at Harvard Business School, whose publication in business and entrepreneurship span over 150 business cases and 3 books, describes the process of writing a great business plan.

item.title: E02: What’s Your Digital Business Model
item.description: Peter Weill and Stephanie Woerner wrote the book What’s Your Digital Business Model for old corporations who have built their business operations on analog infrastructure and now face the need to transform their fundamental business model to compete against companies built for the digital age.

item.title: E01: The Network Imperative
item.description: Authors of The Network Imperative distinguish the network companies from the companies that are not, and describe how network companies see the world differently from their incumbent competitors.

item.title: E02: Pivot - Implementing Network Business Models
item.description: Pivot is a five step process for implementing network business models, proposed by the authors of The Network Imperative. Pivot is an acronym for Pinpoint, Inventory, Visualize, Operate, and Track.

item.title: Launching Interface
item.description: Interface handles frontend and backend so that you can ship your vision apps to users immediately. Links Developer Documentation: https://developer.

item.title: E01: Talking the Winner’s Way
item.description: Leil Lowndes has shaped my attention to details when talking to people, over dinner conversations, in business meetings, and at public talks.

item.title: E02: How to Talk to and Instantly Connect with Anyone
item.description: Leil Lowndes has shaped my attention to details when talking to people, over dinner conversations, in business meetings, and at public talks.

item.title: E03: Making Loyal Friends and Being a Loyal Friend
item.description: Leil Lowndes has shaped my attention to details when talking to people, over dinner conversations, in business meetings, and at public talks.

item.title: E04: Winning Colleagues to Your Side
item.description: Leil Lowndes has shaped my attention to details when talking to people, over dinner conversations, in business meetings, and at public talks.

item.title: E01: Hacking Growth
item.description: There is a difference between building a useful product and building a successful business. Designing and developing a great product is difficult, but is only the first step.

item.title: E02: Building and Operating a Growth Task Force
item.description: The need to build a dedicated growth team The goal of growth hacking is to increase the conversion rate from each stage to the next in the customer funnel.

item.title: E03: Determining If Your Product Is Must Have
item.description: While creating a must-have product alone is not sufficient to achieve a breakout success, it is the baseline requirement for rapid and sustainable growth.

item.title: E04: Testing at High Tempo
item.description: The more experiments you run, the more you learn. It’s really that simple. The high volume is ideal. Big successes in growth hacking come from a series of small wins, compounded over time.

item.title: E05: Hacking Acquisition
item.description: Language Market Fit and Channel Product Fit The first stage of customer funnel is acquisition. Whereas “product market fit” is “being in a good market with a product that can satisfy that market,” authors of Hacking Growth argue that obtaining product market fit is not enough to build a successful business.

item.title: E06: Hacking Activation
item.description: Customer activation An acquired customer, who has tried the product, may not yet fully realize the benefits of the product. Motivating them to realize the full benefits of the product, thereby increasing their engagement, is customer activation.

item.title: E07: Hacking Retention
item.description: Retention Makes and Breaks a Business Peter Drucker asserted that the purpose of business is to create and keep a customer.

item.title: E08: Hacking Monetization
item.description: To reward the employees and shareholders who believed in the business and to fund the next generation of products for the customers, the business needs to secure profit.

item.title: E01: Measure What Matters
item.description: Objectives and Key Results (OKR) framework is widely used in the technology industry for setting objectives and tracking progress. The OKR framework earned its fame after Google in its infancy has adopted the method to brings its projects into order.

item.title: E01: What Makes an Effective Executive
item.description: Peter Drucker is celebrated by business schools and journals as “the father of modern management” (Claremont Graduate University) and “the man who invented management” (Bloomberg BusinessWeek).

item.title: E02: The Origins and Development of Management
item.description: Rarely in human history has any institution emerged as quickly as management or had as great an impact so fast. In less than 150 years, management has transformed the social and economic fabric of the world’s developed countries.

item.title: E03: The Purpose and Objectives of a Business
item.description: Profit is neither evil nor the goal. The widespread concept that an organization exists to make a profit is not only wrong, it is harmful.

item.title: E04: The Accountability of Management
item.description: Businesses are organs of society. Business enterprises, like public service institutions, are organs of society. They do not exist for their own sake, but to fulfill a specific social purpose and to satisfy a specific need of a society, a community, or individuals.

item.title: I am Junwon, Product CEO
item.description: Nice to meet you. I am Junwon Park During the day, I manage visual search products at Microsoft AI & Research, in Bellevue, Washington.

item.title: Launching Product CEO
item.description: A website about product management An enterprise exists to ship great products that enrich the lives of people, thereby strengthening the humankind.
